messages.message:
Sand from the Sahara Desert causing recent lull in the hurricane season: scientistsScientists say tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season.
THE CANADIAN PRESS/HO — Amanda Dunfield, *MANDATORY CREDIT*Original Publication Date July 31, 2024 - 1:01 AMHALIFAX - Tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season, scientists say.
"You can see it in the atmosphere, moving from Africa westward across the Atlantic," says Chris Fogarty, manager of the Canadian Hurricane Centre in Dartmouth, N.S.
Fogarty, however, said hurricane season is sure to pick up in the weeks ahead, with the peak of the season typically arriving in the first few weeks of September.
In late May, the Canadian Hurricane Centre predicted an active hurricane season fuelled by record high ocean temperatures.

HALIFAX – Tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year’s Atlantic hurricane season, scientists say.
Scientists say tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season.
Only three named storms have formed over the Atlantic since hurricane season started on June 1 — tropical storms Alberto and Chris, and hurricane Beryl, which on July 2 became the earliest Category 5 hurricane to be recorded over the Atlantic.
Fogarty, however, said hurricane season is sure to pick up in the weeks ahead, with the peak of the season typically arriving in the first few weeks of September.
“Let’s not wait until these storms are in the news.”In late May, the Canadian Hurricane Centre predicted an active hurricane season fuelled by record high ocean temperatures.

HALIFAX — Tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season, scientists say.
HALIFAX — Tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season, scientists say.
Fogarty, however, said hurricane season is sure to pick up in the weeks ahead, with the peak of the season typically arriving in the first few weeks of September.
Fogarty said now is the time for people in Eastern Canada to prepare for strong winds, heavy rain and storm surges.
In late May, the Canadian Hurricane Centre predicted an active hurricane season fuelled by record high ocean temperatures.

Fogarty said now is the time for people in Eastern Canada to prepare for strong winds, heavy rain and storm surges.
In late May, the Canadian Hurricane Centre predicted an active hurricane season fuelled by record high ocean temperatures.

Tiny grains of sand from the Sahara Desert are to blame for the almost month-long lull in this year's Atlantic hurricane season, scientists say.
And the strong winds that carry the layer along causes wind shear, which can tear storms apart.

LYNDON, Vt. (AP) — Weeks after Jason Pilbin witnessed a driver get swept away by floodwaters, his northeastern Vermont community was ravaged again by flooding from heavy rains.
Nearly three weeks ago, he watched helplessly as a man drowned after getting caught while driving through floodwaters from Hurricane Beryl.
More heavy rains were in the forecast for the state on Wednesday with the possibility of flash flooding.
The fresh flooding yielded similar scenes of catastrophe as the flooding weeks earlier in which two people died, but on a smaller scale.
It came exactly a year after a previous bout of severe flooding hit Vermont and several other states.

LYNDON, Vt. – Weeks after Jason Pilbin witnessed a driver get swept away by floodwaters, his northeastern Vermont community was ravaged again by flooding from heavy rains.
More rain was forecast for central and northern Vermont on Wednesday with the possibility of flash flooding.
The fresh flooding yielded similar scenes of catastrophe as the flooding weeks earlier in which two people died, but on a smaller scale.
It came exactly a year after a previous bout of severe flooding hit Vermont and several other states.
The state’s soil has also been more frequently saturated, and that increases the possibility of flooding, Bancos said.

By Wednesday night, fires had reached Jasper, with flames and smoke so intense it forced first responders to briefly retreat.
Questions and accusations have followed, including from critics who argue Parks Canada and other government agencies did not do enough to protect Jasper.
What were some of the major drivers of the Jasper wildfire?
Wildfire expert Mike Flannigan says the major drivers of the fire were a confluence of several extreme conditions.
Despite the shortcomings, Parks Canada has become one of the most active agencies in Canada for prescribed burns, said Bourbonnais.

Severe storms in the Southeast US leave 1 dead and cause widespread power outagesCANTON, Ga. (AP) — A weather system that produced severe thunderstorms late into the night in the Southeast left one man dead in Georgia, caused damage in a South Carolina town and left hundreds of thousands of electricity customers without power for a time.
Power outages in southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia had declined to about 30,000 by Wednesday morning, down from more than 200,000 in Georgia alone.
In Orangeburg, South Carolina, straight-line winds caused damage in the city's downtown district, blowing down metal from roofs and wood from awnings of downtown businesses.
Officials across southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia said roads were blocked Wednesday because of downed trees and power lines.
Repeated heavy rains and thunderstorms also have struck parts of the Southeast over the last week.

Severe storms in the Southeast US leave 1 dead and cause widespread power outagesA weather system that produced severe thunderstorms in the Southeast left one man dead in Georgia, caused damage in a South Carolina town and left hundreds of thousands of electricity customers without power
